segment.source: Use this method in the Windows Store purchase API to grant a free app or in-app product (IAP) to a given user.
\[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
Use this method in the Windows Store purchase API to grant a free app or in-app product (IAP) to a given user.
Currently, you can only grant free products.
If your service attempts to use this method to grant a product that is not free, this method will return an error.
To use this method, you will need:
An Azure AD access token that was created with the https://onestore.microsoft.com audience URI.
A Windows Store ID key that was generated by calling the GetCustomerPurchaseIdAsync method from client-side code in your app.
For more information, see View and grant products from a service.
The Azure AD access token in the form Bearer token.
Must be set to the value collections.mp.microsoft.com.
The length of the request body.
Specifies the request and response type.
Currently, the only supported value is application/json.
The availability ID of the product to be purchased from the Windows Store catalog.
The Windows Store ID key that represents the customer identity.
A developer-specified offer ID that will appear in the Collection item after purchase.
A GUID generated for the order.
This value be unique for the user, but it is not required to be unique across all orders.
The product ID from the Windows Store catalog.

To obtain your product ID, navigate to your app in the Windows Dev Center dashboard, go to the App management App identity page, and retrieve the suffix of the string shown in the URL for Windows 10 field.
Currently, the only supported value is 1.
If not specified, the default is 1.
The SKU ID from the Windows Store catalog.
Client contextual information for this order.
This will be assigned to the clientID value from the Azure AD token.
The time the order was created.
Currency code for totalAmount and totalTaxAmount.
The friendly name for the order.
N/A for orders made using the Windows Store purchase API.
Indicates whether a payment instrument (PI) is required as part of the purchase order.
The language ID for the order (for example, “en”).
The market ID for the order (for example, “US”).
An ID that identifies the order for a particular user.
The list of line items for the order.
Typically there is 1 line item per order.
The valid states are Editing, CheckingOut, Pending, Purchased, Refunded, ChargedBack, and Cancelled.
The last time the order pricing is valid before it is submitted.
The first time the order pricing is valid before it is submitted.
An object that describes the identity of the purchaser.
The total purchase amount of all items in the order including tax.
Total purchase amount of all items in the order before tax.
If using a separate payment instrument and stored value (CSV), the amount charged to CSV.
The total amount of tax for all line items.
The ClientContext object contains the following parameters.
The client ID that created the order.
The OrderLineItemV6 object contains the following parameters.
The agent that last edited the line item.
For more information about this object, see the table below.
The availability ID of the product to be purchased from the Windows Store catalog.
The identity of the beneficiary of the order.
The billing state of the order.
This is set to Charged when completed.
The campaign ID for this order.
The currency code used for price details.
A localized description of the line item.
The offer ID for the particular order, if present.
The state of the fulfillment of this item.
This is set to Fulfilled when completed.
Indicates whether a payment instrument is required for this line item.
Indicated whether tax is included in the pricing details of the item.
The line item ID for the item in this order.
The list price of the item in this order.
The Windows Store product ID of the line item.
The supported values are Durable, Application, and UnmanagedConsumable.
The quantity of the item ordered.
The retail price of the item ordered.
The Windows Store SKU ID of the line item.
The tax amount for the line item.
The tax type for the applicable taxes.
The localized title of the line item.
The total purchase amount of the line item including tax.
The IdentityV6 object contains the following parameters.
The string value of the publisherUserId from the specified Windows Store ID key.
The Azure AD access token is invalid.
In some cases the details of the ServiceError will contain more information, such as when the token is expired or the appid claim is missing.
An Azure AD access token was not passed to the service in the authorization header.
The clientId claim in the Windows Store ID key in the request body and the appid claim in the Azure AD access token in the authorization header do not match.
The details contain information regarding the request body and which fields have an invalid value.
View and grant products from a service
Renew a Windows Store ID key
